Suppose there are 100 participants in a beauty contest, and each participant must submit a number between 0 and 100 inclusive. The winner will be the participant whose number is closest to two-thirds of the average of all the numbers submitted. 

What number should a participant submit to have the highest chance of winning?
message_2:
Let's analyze the problem using game theory. We will assume that all participants are rational and will submit a number to maximize their chances of winning.

Let x be the average of all the numbers submitted by the 100 participants. The target number to win the contest is (2/3)x.

Since all participants are rational, they will also aim for (2/3)x. Now, let's assume that all participants submit the same number y. In this case, the average x will be equal to y, and the target number will be (2/3)y.

However, if all participants submit (2/3)y, the new average will be (2/3)y, and the new target number will be (2/3)(2/3)y = (4/9)y.

This process will continue iteratively, with each participant adjusting their submitted number to be closer to the target number. The sequence of target numbers will be y, (2/3)y, (4/9)y, (8/27)y, and so on.

This sequence converges to 0 as the number of iterations approaches infinity. Therefore, the best number for a participant to submit, assuming all other participants are rational, is 0. This is known as the "Nash equilibrium" in game theory, where no participant can improve their chances of winning by changing their submitted number if all other participants maintain their current strategy.
